subject: statistics

problem.statementHtml: Construct a histogram to visualize the distribution of exam scores in a class.
hints: Start by determining the number of bins and the range of values.
Use a uniform bin width for simplicity.
The x-axis should represent the score ranges.
problem.solutionHtml:
To construct the histogram, first calculate the frequency of each score.

Then, divide the range of scores into 5-7 bins and plot the frequencies on the y-axis against the corresponding score ranges on the x-axis.

commonMistakes: Not considering the number of students in each bin
Not using a uniform bin width

statementHtml: Consider a dataset of exam scores with outliers. Create a histogram to visualize the distribution.
hints: Start by deciding on the number of bins for your histogram.
Think about how you can adjust the bin width to effectively capture the outliers.
Remember that histograms are sensitive to the choice of binning.
solutionHtml:
To create a histogram, we need to decide on the number and width of the bins. Let's use 5 bins with equal widths.

We can then calculate the frequency of each score in each bin:

\[ egin{array}{|c|c|} \hline Bin & Frequency \ \hline 0-20 & 2 \ \hline 21-40 & 10 \ \hline 41-60 & 15 \ \hline 61-80 & 8 \ \hline 81-100 & 5 \ \hline \end{array} \]

Finally, we can plot the histogram:

\[ \includegraphics[width=0.7 extwidth]{histogram.png} \]",
answerShort: The resulting histogram will show a skewed distribution with outliers." },

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Construct a histogram to visualize the distribution of exam scores in a class.
hints: Start by identifying the range of scores and grouping them into bins.
Consider using a fixed bin width for simplicity.
Think about how you can use the histogram to identify patterns or outliers.
solutionHtml:
To construct the histogram, first calculate the frequency of each score:

\(\[ \text{Frequency} = \sum_{i=1}^{n} I(x_i \in [a, b]) \]\)

Then, divide the range of scores into bins and plot the frequencies:

\( \[ Histogram = \frac{\text{Frequency}}{\Delta x} \] \)

The resulting histogram will show the distribution of exam scores.

",
answerShort: The histogram shows the distribution of exam scores." },

problem.statementHtml: Consider a dataset of exam scores with outliers. Create a histogram to visualize the distribution.
hints: Start by identifying the range of values and the number of data points.
Choose an appropriate bin width for your histogram.
Don't forget to consider the scale on the y-axis.
problem.solutionHtml: To create a histogram, first calculate the frequency of each score. Then, divide the range of scores into bins and plot the frequencies.
problem.answerShort: The resulting histogram will help identify patterns in the data, such as skewness or outliers.

commonMistakes: Forgetting to consider the scale on the y-axis
Choosing too few or too many bins

problem.statementHtml: Consider a dataset of exam scores with outliers. Create a histogram to visualize the distribution.
hints: Start by selecting a suitable bin width.
Use the `hist` function in your preferred programming language or library.
problem.solutionHtml:
Here's one way to solve this problem:

  • Choose a reasonable bin width (e.g., 5-10 points).
  • Use the `hist` function to create the histogram, making sure to include the outliers.
problem.answerShort: The resulting histogram should show the majority of scores clustered around the mean with some outliers visible.

commonMistakes: Choosing an overly narrow or wide bin width
